report_title: Industry Report on Natural Gas Liquid Processing
executive_summary: Natural gas liquid (NGL) production proportionally grows with natural gas extraction. The popularity of advanced extraction techniques like hydraulic fracturing has bolstered shale gas production, giving processors a steady revenue flow. The pandemic weakened industrial production and residential and commercial construction, leading to an oversupply of NGLs and causing prices to plummet. This quickly reversed as the economy reopened and natural gas prices surged, spiking production.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The Ups and Downs of Natural Gas Prices
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Plummeting industrial production amid the pandemic led to manufacturers cutting down their output and purchases of liquified natural gas. Lockdowns also restricted travelling which cut revenue since fuel was not needed. As the economy reopened in 2021, growth from end users surged as the industrial and commercial real estate sectors recovered, leading to massive increases in natural gas liquids. This carried over into 2022, as prices continued to spike.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Processors Face Slower Growth From Residential and Commercial Consumers
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: An unexpectedly mild winter in 2022 and 2023 has greatly reduced the residential and commercial consumption of NGLs for heating. According to meteorologists, the last two winters were some of the warmest winters of all time. These warm changes stemmed from El Nino, which is a climate phenomenon that warms the ocean surface, causing temperatures to swell.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Exports Were a Boon to NGL Processors
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Following Russia's invasion of Ukraine, Russia reduced its exports of natural gas liquids, opening the door for domestic producers to accelerate their European exports as countries looked to hike supply. The explosion of the Nordstream pipelines compounded the growth of domestic exports to Europe as that pipeline was a crucial natural gas pipeline from Russia to Europe.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Production Boom Keeps the Need for Processors Elevated
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Since NGLs are a byproduct of natural gas processing, an uptick in production bolsters NGL production. Gas extraction has boomed domestically because of newly discovered natural gas deposits alongside advances in technology that help retrieve them. Hydraulic fracturing, or fracking, allows extraction companies to tap into shale gas reserves or natural gas trapped in shale formations.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As oil and gas production continues to climb through 2029, processors will enjoy steady volumes. Industrial production will also remain steady, supporting growth from end users like plastic manufacturers and energy producers. Despite these circumstances, revenue is set to dip throughout the outlook period as natural gas prices continue to plummet after massive hikes during.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Supply Woes Slowly Dwindle Keeping Exports Level Headed
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As Europe continues to reduce its reliance on Russian NGLs, exports to Europe will continue to expand and support growth. The UK will remain a key export destination for NGL processors as the country banned Russian NGL imports in January 2023, providing a steady export destination for processors. While export volumes will remain elevated, price drops will cause the value of exports to fall. Even so, exports will continue to account for over two-thirds of revenue.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Green Initiatives Pressure Natural Gas Liquid Processors
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The push towards sustainability will continue to pose a threat to processing plants. Under the Inflation Reduction act, in 2026, there will be a $900.0 fee per ton of methane emissions; in 2028, the fee will jump to $1500.0 per ton. While this bill will create headwinds for processors, it will provide $1.6 billion to help finance and provide technical support to industries dealing with natural gas to reduce methane emissions.

industry_definition: This industry separates out natural gas liquids (NGLs) from natural gas. Natural gas arrives at processing facilities in a gaseous state, and processors clean the natural gas and extract liquid hydrocarbons including ethane, propane, butane, isobutane and natural gasoline. These liquids have various uses including home heating fuel, inputs in plastic products and heating or blowing fuel in industrial production. The production of NGLs from oil refining is not included in this industry.

opportunities: High Performance Drivers - US oil and gas production index
threats: Low Outlier Growth - Price of natural gas

key_trends: Processors compete on price and operating capacity. Companies with greater operating capacity and efficiency have an advantage over smaller processors.

Natural gas liquids face external competition from other refiners. While petroleum refiners do produce natural gas liquids, their output is significantly lower compared to the production from natural gas liquid processing plants.
As prices push down from historical highs, revenue will contract. Even so, expanding natural gas extract will provide processors with a steady stream of business.

Warmer winters in 2022 and 2023, resulting from El Nino, drastically reduced the need for natural gas liquids for heating. Consumers are also opting for more sustainable electric appliances, which help lower their carbon footprint despite higher upfront costs.

market_segmentation.segment: Natural gas lease and plant fuel
market_segmentation.segment_description: This market comprises energy producers using natural gas liquids as an input and as a fuel source. Refineries and gasoline producers blend natural gasoline and pentane into motor gasoline.

Petrochemical manufacturers are significant consumers of natural gas liquids for use in industrial feedstock and to process ethane to produce ethylene, a major input for plastic and resin manufacturers. Manufacturers convert isobutane into refrigerants and as blending agents for gasoline. Manufacturers also process butane to produce cigarette lighter fluid and aerosol propellants.

This market comprises distributors transporting natural gas liquids through pipelines for eventual end-use. European trade tensions with Russian, compounded by the explosion of the Nordstream pipelines, led to surging exports to Europe, allowing this market to expand. Even so, this segment was slightly hindered as gas pipeline capacity addition dipped throughout the period. Many of these delays stemmed from the pandemic and continue to impact contractors today.

This market comprises households and businesses using natural gas liquids for heating, cooking and vehicle fuel. Propane is the most commonly used natural gas liquid in this market. Warm winters in 2022 and 2023 drastically reduced domestic propane consumption. The market also suffered as consumers increasingly switch to electric-powered appliances. Tax incentives for purchasing these electric appliances have further discouraged propane use, as consumers aim to adopt more sustainable practices.

This market comprises households and businesses using natural gas liquids for heating, cooking and vehicle fuel. Propane is the most commonly used natural gas liquid in this market. Warm winters in 2022 and 2023 drastically reduced domestic propane consumption. The market also suffered as consumers increasingly switch to electric-powered appliances. Tax incentives for purchasing these electric appliances have further discouraged propane use, as consumers aim to adopt more sustainable practices.

products_and_services.product_description: Pentane plus and natural gasoline, primarily used as vehicle fuel. Manufacturers use pentane plus as a gasoline-blending agent. Some vehicles can use natural gasoline directly, but it is typically blended with other products to produce aviation and vehicle fuel.
Ethanol, the primary input in ethylene production to manufacture various plastic products. Ethanol can also combine with gasoline to power flexible fuel vehicles.
Propane, used for heating, cooking and vehicles. Propane is one of the most widely produced and consumed natural gas liquids (by volume).

Butane, often used as a gasoline blending agent and feedstock for ethylene production. Butane can be blended with propane to produce liquefied petroleum gases for petrochemical manufacturing. Manufacturers use a mixture of butane and propane mixture as fuel for cigarette lighters and as a propellant in aerosol sprays.
Isobutane, used as a refrigerant and in aerosol sprays. Isobutane's primary application in the US is as a chemical feedstock for alkylate, a high-octane additive to gasoline.

tier_1_suppliers: Oil Drilling & Gas Extraction in the US
Oil & Gas Pipeline Construction in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Gasoline & Petroleum Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Agriculture, Forestry, Fishing and Hunting in the US
Oil Drilling & Gas Extraction in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Natural gas liquids (NGLs) are a byproduct of natural gas processing, which means that natural gas production directly affects NGL production. Both natural gas and NGLs share various applications, such as heating homes and offices. A climb in the price of natural gas often pushes up the price of NGLs, boosting revenue for NGL processors.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: US Oil and Gas Production Index
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Natural gas liquids (NGLs) are produced as a byproduct of natural gas production and oil refining, although the industry does not include oil refining. When energy production increases, more oil and gas are processed, effectively boosting the production of NGLs, which represents a potential opportunity for processors. A drop in production may constrain NGL supply, negatively impacting processor profitability and market dynamics.

The trade-weighted index (TWI) measures the strength of the US dollar against the currencies of its major US trading partners. When the TWI increases, US products become more expensive on the global market, making them less attractive to foreign buyers. An increase in the TWI can lead to a dip in overall demand for natural gas liquids, posing a potential threat to processors.

Fuel dealers directly sell natural gas liquids (NGLs) like propane and heating oil to consumers and industrial buyers for heating and fuel purposes. The need for these types of NGLs can fluctuate yearly, depending on the severity of weather conditions in high-selling regions, especially New England and the Mid-Atlantic regions. An uptick in revenue for fuel duelers typically indicates a higher need for NGLs, which pushes up industry revenue.

The industrial production index (IPI) directly influences NGL processing by dictating sales from manufacturing sectors. As the IPI rises, industries ramp production, bolstering their need for natural gas liquids as feedstocks and energy sources. This heightened demand drives revenue for NGL processing, showcasing a robust relationship where growth in industrial activity fuels gains.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Imports fell, but not as much as domestic production increased
international_trade_points.trade_description: As US natural gas producers have ramped up production to take advantage of the favorable price environment amid European supply chain woes, imports have fallen. Imports have fallen slower than domestic production, which has increased because natural gas producers are exporting much of their production, diminishing the available supply for domestic us. This trend has forced downstream customers of natural gas liquids to import natural gas liquids for less favorable prices, keeping imports high.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Canada is the primary source of imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Canada is the third largest producer of natural gas liquids and imports account for more than half of the US's imports.

international_trade_points.trade_title: GLOBAL SUPPLY CHAIN WOES PUSH UP EXPORTS
international_trade_points.trade_description: Russia has reduced its natural gas liquid exports to Europe following the country's invasion of Ukraine, resulting in supply shortages and massive price increases. The explosion of Nordstream 1 and 2 compounded these supply woes. US exports to Europe have increased to take advantage of this favorable price environment.

international_trade_points.trade_title: EXPORTS TO THE UNITED KINGDOM AND JAPAN SURGE
international_trade_points.trade_description: The United Kingdom previously imported large quantities of Russian natural gas liquids but reduced imports in 2022 and banned all imports in 2023, leading to US exports to the country spike.

business_locations.location_description: Natural gas processors establish in Texas because of the Barnett Shale, Eagle Ford Shale and Permian Basin, three major oil and gas extraction sites in the US.
Louisiana is the US's third largest natural gas producer, attracting natural gas processors.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The NSPS regulates natural gas compressors, pneumatic controllers, leak detection and other processing-plant technology.

regulations_points.regulation_title: THE NATIONAL EMISSIONS STANDARDS FOR HAZARDOUS AIR POLLUTANTS (NESHAPS)
regulations_points.regulation_description: NESHAPS are broad standards for hazardous air pollutants.
Within the Inflation Reduction Act, there are new penalties for methane emissions.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The natural gas liquid processing industry is mature.

basis_points.basis_description: Processors compete on price and operating capacity. Companies with greater operating capacity and efficiency have an advantage over smaller processors.
Natural gas liquids face external competition from other refiners.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Market share concentration is low because it is difficult for even the largest natural gas liquid processors to control more than a small share of output.
The size of a natural gas liquid processor's pipeline infrastructure impacts its ability to accumulate market share.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation Costs Remain High as Production Expands
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation costs have remained a steady portion of revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Dip Despite Surging Commodity Prices
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases represent costs for chemicals required for natural gas liquid processing.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Removing natural gas liquids from natural gas through several complex industrial processes requires heavy-duty machinery.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Consumer Preferences Impact Revenue for Processors
volatility_points.volatility_description: Individuals primarily use propane to heat and power portable generators.

volatility_points.volatility_title: NGL Processors Rely on the Industrial Sector
volatility_points.volatility_description: Manufacturers use natural gas liquids to power their facilities.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Environmental Regulation Weaken Traditional Energy Sources
volatility_points.volatility_description: Environmental regulations targeting air emissions contribute to revenue volatility.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: THE IMPLEMENTATION OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE DURING THE PROCESSING
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: AI transforms natural gas liquid processing by continuously monitoring key parameters.
Advanced cryogenic units operate at extremely low temperatures.

FAQs.question: Does your company focus on one form of NGL, or do you produce a variety of NGLs?
FAQs.answer: Due to the nature of processing natural gas into various liquid products, companies often produce a variety of NGLs, though some have built plants specializing in the production of a specific NGL.

FAQs.question: Are your company's sales heavily dependent on the health of the US economy?
FAQs.answer: Economic growth drives demand for the industry's products, but sales are far more dependent on the price of their commoditized products.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Like other petroleum and gas-based industries, companies in this industry rely on generous pay to keep talented engineers.

FAQs.question: Has your company dealt with volatile commodity prices over the past few years?
FAQs.answer: NGL prices are subject to many of the same forces that other petroleum products face, so they are volatile.

FAQs.question: Is your company leveraging digital technologies, such as software and wireless processes, to better track operations in real time?
FAQs.answer: Increased digitization of the industry has improved efficiency.

FAQs.question: Have you been able to use automation to reduce wage costs over the past five years?
FAQs.answer: Processing is a highly capital-intensive activity requiring minimal contribution from employees.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure all health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Given the nature of the industry's products (i.e., they are flammable), companies in this industry follow specific guidelines set by OSHA.

FAQs.question: Have any regulatory expenses significantly impacted profitability recently?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry face scrutiny from the Environmental Protection Agency and state-level equivalents.

FAQs.question: How do seasonal factors affect your company's revenue and cash flow?
FAQs.answer: Cold winters can be a boon to industry revenue as lower temperatures boost demand.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Profit is similar among processors because the industry is highly fragmented.

FAQs.question: Access to highly skilled workforce
FAQs.answer: Similar to the oil and gas sector, NGL processing is highly technical.

FAQs.question: Ability to pass on cost increases
FAQs.answer: NGL prices are dependent on oil and gas prices.

FAQs.question: Proximity to key markets
FAQs.answer: Raw natural gas must be processed before it can be delivered to consumers.

FAQs.question: Price of natural gas
FAQs.answer: Natural gas liquids (NGLs) are a byproduct of natural gas processing.

FAQs.question: How does the industrial production index affect your company? Do you monitor this level?
FAQs.answer: Natural gas liquids (NGLs) have a variety of industrial uses.

FAQs.question: How does increasing oil and gas production affect the volume of NGL processing? Do you monitor oil and gas production volumes?
FAQs.answer: Natural gas liquids (NGLs) are produced as a byproduct of both natural gas production and oil refining.
